instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00165A: What is 820-00165A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a missing <SIGNAL>PP1V0S_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[h=2]FWD: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - fan spins, no <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>[/h] 1 minute ago
Hi, Good Day,

I have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board, no PP1V05-S0. water damaged near <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> area.
I replaced <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> with a new chip check the resistors around and all fine.

Here are the voltages I get.
<RESISTOR>R7600</RESISTOR> =5V
<RESISTOR>R7630</RESISTOR> =4.9V PIN(1&2 BOTH)
<CAPACITOR>C7630</CAPACITOR> PIN 1 =4.9V PIN 2 =0V
<RESISTOR>R8138</RESISTOR> =3.3V
<CAPACITOR>C7616</CAPACITOR> =1.0V
<CAPACITOR>C7615</CAPACITOR> =1.8V
<RESISTOR>R7631</RESISTOR> =0V
<RESISTOR>R7641</RESISTOR> =0V

Also in <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> pin 10 which is GND pad is missing. I found shorted <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>. I removed <RESISTOR>R7320</RESISTOR> &<RESISTOR>R7310</RESISTOR> & found shorted in PCH side (<RESISTOR>R7320</RESISTOR> pin 2 & <RESISTOR>R7310</RESISTOR> pin1). Can You pls help to sort this out?

Thanks
Regards
Don

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a missing <SIGNAL>PP1V0S_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Be aware that <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is supposed to have a low resistance to ground, (of just a few ohms). So unless it's a dead short there is nothing wrong 
What is the resistance of <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> to ground?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a missing <SIGNAL>PP1V0S_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hi, Thank you for your information as i didnt know that. it is 0.002 ohms. is that normal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a missing <SIGNAL>PP1V0S_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You're comparing with one of the leads to ground right? Because that is a actual short to ground then

On what line is this? Or on both?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a missing <SIGNAL>PP1V0S_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hi Smiba. So sorry not to reply you, as I was out of the  country. I sorted out the issue and all good. thank you so much for your help.
